title: What would happen if the Earth were to slow down? - Quora

response.answer_text: Wow there is a lot of disparity on the answers for this one! First, regarding the atmosphere: Some planets rotate much faster than Earth (Jupiter) and some much slower (Venus).  Both of these have massively thick atmospheres.  Mars, which rotates at roughly the same rate as the Earth has very little atmosphere.  So I disagree with the answers that are saying the Earth's atmosphere would redistribute or radically alter in some way.  Earth once rotated much faster than it now does, and it had a thick atmosphere at that time.  As it slowed down, it maintained its atmosphere.  My bet is that a 1/3rd slowing would temporarily shake up the atmosphere, but not redistribute it in any long term way. Second, regarding temperature:  I don't there'd be much difference here, either.  There are places were it is dark for months at a time and then light for months at a time.  These places (the poles) are chillier than the rest of the planet, to be sure, but not ridiculously so.  And the sunlight they do get is very weak due to the long angles. So while there would be greater cooling at night (though how much remains subject to debate here), there would be greater warming during the day.  This greater warming would drive more powerful winds and storms than we currently have, but these would have the effect of mixing the atmosphere more quickly and thoroughly, which would redistribute the heat.  Also, that increased heat on the daytime side would increase atmospheric humidity levels.  Since water is a greenhouse gas, this would serve to warm the planet.  Again, this would mitigate nighttime cooling. Third, regarding the core:  The rotation of the core is very complex, and not directly tied to the rotation of the Earth as a whole.  We know this because the poles switch their polarity from time to time, and this appears to have nothing to do with the rotation of the Earth.  It's certainly possible that slowing the Earth would reduce the magnetic field, but it would not necessarily do so.  If we just slowed the planet as a whole, the core might continue to spin as it does now - it does have a rather enormous amount of inertia! So, all in all, I would take some of these answers with a grain of salt.  There would certainly be impacts, but what those would be is far from certain.

I'm not sure about the effects ion the planet's core, but the climatic effects are much more vast than hotter days and colder nights. The temperature differences would make the oceans' streams change dramatically. All climate would be affected. Forests could turn to deserts, deserts could start to receive more and more rain and become fertile terrain. Droughts, ice, completely different seasons... Not to mention that a slower rotation could make the sea levels lower near the equator and raise near the poles, as there would be less centrifugal forces applied to the planet's water masses. This very same mechanism could put some stress on the planet's crust, so vulcanism and earthquakes could be possibly expected as well.

Would it get hotter in the day and colder in night? Yes. How much?  The average temperature on Earth is 15°C. The temperature amplitude (Max - Min) in a day around where I live is typically 10°C. It’s less near the sea and more further inland. I live 300 km from the nearest sea so I’m a good average. The average would stay the same and the amplitude would triple. In spring and autumn, we’d freeze every night and have a few hours of beach-worthy temperature every afternoon. Winters would be much more pleasant, freezing past -10°C at night, but we’d have 20°C some afternoons. Summers afternoon would average at 35°C, with the occasional 50, I’m sure. But it’d still be survivable. For us. The relocation of the atmosphere and oceans (due to the Earth bulge not resorbing as fast as them) will already kill off half the biosphere. The temperature extremes will do half of what’s left in. Including 100% of our crops. Our new everyday will also involve much more powerful winds than before because wind is caused by temperature differentials. But, the superstorms we’ll get used to will still feel like nothing compared to the megastorms caused by the slowdown. Not so survivable after all…

The earth IS slowing down—by about 20 milionths of a second each year. This is caused by tidal forces generated by the moon. At the same time these forces cause the moon to get about 4cm further away each year. If you mean what would happen if the earth suddenly slowed down significantly or even stopped rotating then we would experience hurricane winds—about 1,000 mph, 500 mile high tidal waves and probably the meltdown of the earth’s crust. All that rotational energy has to go somewhere!
